chapter.title: Boost.DateTime
chapter.para: The library Boost.DateTime can be used to process time data such as calendar dates and times. In addition, Boost.DateTime provides extensions to account for time zones and supports formatted input and output of calendar dates and times. If you are looking for functions to get the current time or measure time, see Boost.Chrono in .

sect1.title: Calendar Dates
sect1.para: Boost.DateTime only supports calendar dates based on the Gregorian calendarGregorian calendar, which in general is not a problem since this is the most widely used calendar. If you arrange a meeting with someone for May 12, 2014, you don’t need to say that the date is based on the Gregorian calendar.

The Gregorian calendar was introduced by Pope Gregory XIII in 1582. Boost.DateTime supports calendar dates for the years 1400 to 9999, which means that support goes back before the year 1582. Thus, you can use Boost.DateTime for any calendar date after the year 1400 as long as that date is converted to the Gregorian calendar. To process earlier dates, Boost.DateTime has to be extended by a new calendar.

The header file boost/date_time/gregorian/gregorian.hpp contains definitions for all classes and functions that process calendar dates. These functions and classes can be found in the namespace boost::gregorian. To create a date, use the class boost::gregorian::dategregorian::datedate, gregorian.

boost::gregorian::date provides several constructors to create dates. The most basic constructor takes a year, a month, and a day as parameters. If an invalid value is given, an exception will be thrown of type boost::gregorian::bad_day_of_monthgregorian::bad_day_of_monthbad_day_of_month, gregorian, boost::gregorian::bad_yeargregorian::bad_yearbad_year, gregorian, or boost::gregorian::bad_monthgregorian::bad_monthbad_month, gregorian. All of these classes are derived from std::out_of_range.

As shown in , there are many member functions available. Some member functions, such as yeargregorian::date::yearyear, gregorian::date, monthgregorian::date::monthmonth, gregorian::date, and daygregorian::date::dayday, gregorian::date, return the respective parts of a date, and others, such as day_of_weekgregorian::date::day_of_weekday_of_week, gregorian::date and end_of_monthgregorian::date::end_of_monthend_of_month, gregorian::date, calculate values.

The constructor of boost::gregorian::date expects numeric values for year, month, and day to set a date. However, the output of the sample program is Jan for the month and Fri for the day of the week. The return values of month and day_of_week are not regular numeric values, but values of type boost::gregorian::date::month_typegregorian::date::month_typemonth_type, gregorian::date and boost::gregorian::date::day_of_week_typegregorian::date::day_of_week_typeday_of_week_type, gregorian::date. Boost.DateTime provides comprehensive support for formatted input and output, so it is possible to adjust the output from, for example, Jan to 1.

The default constructor of boost::gregorian::date creates an invalid date. An invalid date can also be created explicitly by passing boost::date_time::not_a_date_timedate_time::not_a_date_timenot_a_date_time, date_time as the sole parameter to the constructor.
Besides calling a constructor directly, an object of type boost::gregorian::date can be created via free-standing functions and member functions of other classes.

example.title: Getting a date from a clock or a string

sect1.para: uses the class boost::gregorian::day_clockgregorian::day_clockday_clock, gregorian, which returns the current date. The member function universal_daygregorian::day_clock::universal_dayuniversal_day, gregorian::day_clock returns a UTC date, which is independent of time zones and daylight savings. UTC is the international abbreviation for the universal time. boost::gregorian::day_clock also provides a member function called local_daygregorian::day_clock::local_daylocal_day, gregorian::day_clock, which takes local settings into account. To retrieve the current date within the local time zone, use local_day.

The namespace boost::gregorian contains free-standing functions to convert a date stored as a string into an object of type boost::gregorian::date. converts a date in the ISO 8601 format using the function boost::gregorian::date_from_iso_stringgregorian::date_from_iso_stringdate_from_iso_string, gregorian. Other functions include: boost::gregorian::from_simple_stringgregorian::from_simple_stringfrom_simple_string, gregorian and boost::gregorian::from_us_stringgregorian::from_us_stringfrom_us_string, gregorian.
While boost::gregorian::date marks a specific time, boost::gregorian::date_durationgregorian::date_durationdate_duration, gregorian denotes a duration.

Because boost::gregorian::date overloads operator-, two points in time can be subtracted (see ). The return value is of type boost::gregorian::date_duration and marks the duration between the two dates.

The most important member function offered by boost::gregorian::date_duration is daysgregorian::date_duration::daysdays, gregorian::date_duration, which returns the number of days in the duration specified.

Objects of type boost::gregorian::date_duration can also be created by passing the number of days as a single parameter to the constructor. To create a duration that involves weeks, months, or years, use boost::gregorian::weeksgregorian::weeksweeks, gregorian, boost::gregorian::monthsgregorian::monthsmonths, gregorian, or boost::gregorian::yearsgregorian::yearsyears, gregorian (see ).

Neither boost::gregorian::months nor boost::gregorian::years will allow you to determine the number of days, because months and years vary in length. Nonetheless, using these classes can still make sense, as shown in .

adds one month to the given date of January 31, 2014, which results in d2 being February 28, 2014. In the next step, one month is subtracted and d3 becomes January 31, 2014, again. As shown, points in time as well as durations can be used in calculations. However, some specifics need to be taken into account. For example, starting at the last day of a month, boost::gregorian::months always arrives at the last day of another month, which can lead to surprises.

is identical to the previous one, except d is initialized to be January 30, 2014. Even though this is not the last day in January, jumping forward by one month results in d2 becoming February 28, 2014, because there is no February 30. However, jumping backwards by one month again results in d3 becoming January 31, 2014. Since February 28, 2014, is the last day in February, jumping backwards returns to the last day in January.

To change this behavior, undefine the macro BOOST_DATE_TIME_OPTIONAL_GREGORIAN_TYPESBOOST_DATE_TIME_OPTIONAL_GREGORIAN_TYPES, Boost.DateTime. After this macro is undefined, the classes boost::gregorian::weeks, boost::gregorian::months, and boost::gregorian::years will no longer be available. The only class still available will be boost::gregorian::date_duration, which simply jumps forwards and backwards by a specified number of days and does not give special consideration to the first and last day of the month.
While boost::gregorian::date_duration only works with durations, boost::gregorian::date_periodgregorian::date_perioddate_period, gregorian supports ranges between two dates.

The constructor of boost::gregorian::date_period can accept two kinds of input. You can pass two parameters of type boost::gregorian::date, one for the beginning date and one for the end date. Or you can specify the beginning date and a duration of type boost::gregorian::date_duration. Please note that the day before the end date is actually the last day of the period. This is important in order to understand the output of .

example.title: Testing whether a period contains dates

sect1.para: checks whether a specific date is within a period by calling containsgregorian::date_period::containscontains, gregorian::date_period. Notice that although d2 defines the end of the period, it is not considered part of the period. Therefore, the member function contains will return true when called with d1 and false when called with d2.
boost::gregorian::date_period provides additional member functions for operations such as shifting a period or calculating the intersection of two overlapping periods.
Boost.DateTime also provides iterators and other useful free-standing functions as shown in .

Use the iterator boost::gregorian::day_iteratorgregorian::day_iteratorday_iterator, gregorian to jump forward or backward by a day from a specific date. Use boost::gregorian::week_iteratorgregorian::week_iteratorweek_iterator, gregorian, boost::gregorian::month_iteratorgregorian::month_iteratormonth_iterator, gregorian, and boost::gregorian::year_iteratorgregorian::year_iteratoryear_iterator, gregorian to jump by weeks, months, or years, respectively.

also uses the function boost::date_time::next_weekdaydate_time::next_weekdaynext_weekday, date_time, which returns the date of the next weekday based on a given date. displays 2014-May-16, which is the first Friday following May 13, 2014.

sect1.title: Location-independent Times
sect1.para: The class boost::posix_time::ptimeposix_time::ptimeptime, posix_time defines a location-independent time. It uses the type boost::gregorian::date, but also stores a time. To use boost::posix_time::ptime, include the header file boost/date_time/posix_time/posix_time.hpp.

To initialize an object of type boost::posix_time::ptime, pass a date of type boost::gregorian::date and a duration of type boost::posix_time::time_duration as the first and second parameters to the constructor. The constructor of boost::posix_time::time_duration takes three parameters, which determine the time. specifies 12 PM on May 12, 2014, as the point in time. To query date and time, use the member functions dateposix_time::ptime::datedate, posix_time::ptime and time_of_dayposix_time::ptime::time_of_daytime_of_day, posix_time::ptime.

Just as the default constructor of boost::gregorian::date creates an invalid date, the default constructor of boost::posix_time::ptime creates an invalid time. An invalid time can also be created explicitly by passing boost::date_time::not_a_date_timedate_time::not_a_date_timenot_a_date_time, date_time to the constructor. Boost.DateTime provides free-standing functions and member functions to create times that are analogous to those used to create calendar dates of type boost::gregorian::date.

example.title: Creating a timepoint with a clock or a string

sect1.para: The class boost::posix_time::second_clockposix_time::second_clocksecond_clock, posix_time returns the current time. The member function universal_timeposix_time::second_clock::universal_timeuniversal_time, posix_time::second_clock returns the UTC time (see ). local_timeposix_time::second_clock::local_timelocal_time, posix_time::second_clock returns the local time. If you need a higher resolution, boost::posix_time::microsec_clockposix_time::microsec_clockmicrosec_clock, posix_time returns the current time including microseconds.

The free-standing function boost::posix_time::from_iso_stringposix_time::from_iso_stringfrom_iso_string, posix_time converts a time stored in a string formatted using the ISO 8601 standard into an object of type boost::posix_time::ptime.

Boost.DateTime also provides the class boost::posix_time::time_durationposix_time::time_durationtime_duration, posix_time, which specifies a duration. This class has been mentioned before because the constructor of boost::posix_time::ptime expects an object of type boost::posix_time::time_duration as its second parameter. You can also use boost::posix_time::time_duration independently.

hoursposix_time::time_duration::hourshours, posix_time::time_duration, minutesposix_time::time_duration::minutesminutes, posix_time::time_duration, and secondsposix_time::time_duration::secondsseconds, posix_time::time_duration return the respective parts of a time duration, while member functions such as total_secondsposix_time::time_duration::total_secondstotal_seconds, posix_time::time_duration, which returns the total number of seconds, provide additional information (see ). There is no upper limit, such as 24 hours, to the values you can legally pass to boost::posix_time::time_duration.

As with calendar dates, calculations can be performed with points in time and durations. If two times of type boost::posix_time::ptime are subtracted from each other, as in , the result is an object of type boost::posix_time::time_duration that specifies the duration between the two times.
As shown in , a duration can be added to a time, resulting in a new point in time. This example writes 18:30:00 to the standard output stream.

Boost.DateTime uses the same concepts for calendar dates and times. Just as there are classes for times and durations, there is also one for periods. For calendar dates, this is boost::gregorian::date_period; for times it is boost::posix_time::time_periodposix_time::time_periodtime_period, posix_time. The constructors of both classes expect two parameters: boost::gregorian::date_period expects two calendar dates as parameters and boost::posix_time::time_period expects two points in time.

In general, boost::posix_time::time_period works just like boost::gregorian::date_period. It provides a member function, containsposix_time::time_period::containscontains, posix_time::time_period, which returns true for every point in time within the period. Because the end time, which is passed to the constructor of boost::posix_time::time_period, is not part of the period, the second call to contains in returns false.

boost::posix_time::time_period provides additional member functions such as intersectionposix_time::time_period::intersectionintersection, posix_time::time_period and mergeposix_time::time_period::mergemerge, posix_time::time_period, which respectively, calculate the intersection of two overlapping periods and merge two intersecting periods.
Finally, the iterator boost::posix_time::time_iteratorposix_time::time_iteratortime_iterator, posix_time iterates over points in time.
uses the iterator it to jump forward 6.5 hours from the time pt. Because the iterator is incremented twice, the output is 2014-May-12 18:30:00 and 2014-May-13 01:00:00.

sect1.title: Location-dependent Times
sect1.para: Unlike the location-independent times introduced in the previous section, location-dependent times account for time zones. Boost.DateTime provides the class boost::local_time::local_date_timelocal_time::local_date_timelocal_date_time, local_time, which is defined in boost/date_time/local_time/local_time.hpp. This class stores time-zone related data using boost::local_time::posix_time_zonelocal_time::posix_time_zoneposix_time_zone, local_time.

The constructor of boost::local_time::local_date_time expects its first parameter to be an object of type boost::posix_time::ptime and its second parameter to be an object of type boost::local_time::time_zone_ptrlocal_time::time_zone_ptrtime_zone_ptr, local_time. boost::local_time::time_zone_ptr is a type definition for boost::shared_ptr<boost::local_time::time_zone>. The type definition is based on boost::local_time::time_zone, not boost::local_time::posix_time_zone. That’s fine because boost::local_time::posix_time_zone is derived from boost::local_time::time_zonelocal_time::time_zonetime_zone, local_time. This makes it possible to extend Boost.DateTime with user-defined types for time zones.

No object of type boost::local_time::posix_time_zone is passed. Instead, a smart pointer referring to the object is passed. This allows multiple objects of type boost::local_time::local_date_time to share time-zone data. When the last object is destroyed, the object representing the time zone will automatically be released.

To create an object of type boost::local_time::posix_time_zone, a string describing the time zone is passed to the constructor as the only parameter. specifies Central Europe as the time zone (CET is the abbreviation for Central European Time). Since CET is one hour ahead of UTC, the deviation is represented as +1. Boost.DateTime is not able to interpret abbreviations for time zones and thus does not know the meaning of CET. Therefore, the deviation must always be provided in hours; use the value +0 if there is no deviation.

The program writes the strings 2014-May-12 12:00:00, 2014-May-12 13:00:00 CET, 2014-May-12 13:00:00, and CET to the standard output stream. Values used to initialize objects of type boost::posix_time::ptime and boost::local_time::local_date_time always relate to the UTC time zone by default. When an object of type boost::local_time::local_date_time is written to the standard output stream or a call to the member function local_timelocal_time::local_date_time::local_timelocal_time, local_time::local_date_time is made, the deviation in hours is used to calculate the local time.

example.title: Location-dependent points in time and different time zones

sect1.para: With local_time, the deviation for the time zone is respected. In order to calculate the CET time, one hour needs to be added to the UTC time of 12 PM stored in dt, since CET is one hour ahead of UTC. That’s why local_time writes 2014-May-12 13:00:00 to standard output in .

In contrast, the member function local_time_inlocal_time::local_date_time::local_time_inlocal_time_in, local_time::local_date_time interprets the time stored in dt as being in the time zone that is passed as a parameter. This means that 12 PM UTC equals 2 PM EET which stands for Eastern European Time and is two hours ahead of UTC.
Finally, Boost.DateTime provides the class boost::local_time::local_time_periodlocal_time::local_time_periodlocal_time_period, local_time for location-dependent periods.

The constructor of boost::local_time::local_time_period in expects two parameters of type boost::local_time::local_date_timelocal_time::local_date_timelocal_date_time, local_time. As with other types provided for periods, the second parameter, which represents the end time, is not part of the period. With the help of member functions such as containslocal_time::local_time_period::containscontains, local_time::local_time_period, intersectionlocal_time::local_time_period::intersectionintersection, local_time::local_time_period, mergelocal_time::local_time_period::mergemerge, local_time::local_time_period, and others, you can process periods based on boost::local_time::local_time_period.

sect1.title: Formatted Input and Output
sect1.para: The sample programs described so far in this chapter write results in the format 2014-May-12. Boost.DateTime lets you display results in different formats. Calendar dates and times can be formatted using boost::date_time::date_facetdate_time::date_facetdate_facet, date_time and boost::date_time::time_facetdate_time::time_facettime_facet, date_time.

Boost.DateTime uses the concept of locales from the standard. To format a calendar date, an object of type boost::date_time::date_facet must be created and installed within a locale. A string describing the new format is passed to the constructor of boost::date_time::date_facet. passes %A, %d %B %Y, which specifies that the day of the week is followed by the date with the month written in full: Monday, 12 May 2014.

example.title: A user-defined format for a date

sect1.para: Boost.DateTime provides numerous format flags, each of which consists of the percent sign followed by a character. The documentation for Boost.DateTime contains a complete overview of all supported flags.
If a program is used by people located in Germany or German-speaking countries, it is preferable to display both the weekday and the month in German rather than in English.

example.title: Changing names of weekdays and months

sect1.para: The names for weekdays and months can be changed by passing vectors containing the desired names to the member functions long_month_namesgregorian::date_facet::long_month_nameslong_month_names, gregorian::date_facet and long_weekday_namesgregorian::date_facet::long_weekday_nameslong_weekday_names, gregorian::date_facet of the class boost::date_time::date_facet. now writes Montag, 12. Mai 2014 to the standard output stream.

note.para: To run the example on a POSIX operating system, replace German with de_DE and make sure the locale for German is installed.

sect1.para: Boost.DateTime is flexible with regard to formatted input and output. Besides the output classes boost::date_time::date_facet and boost::date_time::time_facet, the classes boost::date_time::date_input_facetdate_time::date_input_facetdate_input_facet, date_time and boost::date_time::time_input_facetdate_time::time_input_facettime_input_facet, date_time are available for formatted input. All four classes provide member functions to configure the input and output of different objects provided by Boost.DateTime. For example, it is possible to specify how periods of type boost::gregorian::date_period are input and output. To see all of the possibilities for formatted input and output, review the documentation for Boost.DateTime.
